occurrences.line_text: So well he woo'd her, and so well he wrought her,
Walkt through the wood, for pleasure, or for need;
And as he through the wandring wood did stray,
Till on a day as through that wood he rode,
From day to day she woo'd and prayd him fast,
Against those two let driue, as they were wood:
The raging Buls rebellow through the wood,
Like a wood God, and flowing fast to Rhy:
The pleasaunt Bandon crownd with many a wood,
With whom whiles he did in the wood remaine,
And whether he did woo, or whether he were woo'd.
That made him raue, like to a Lyon wood,
Can not come neare him in the couert wood,
Vnto the wyld wood ranne, her dolours to deplore.
But she them woo'd by all the meanes she might,
And like a Lion wood amongst them fares,
Within a wood, whereas a Ladie gent
And range through all the wood, where so he wist
Into the wood was bearing her apace
And running streight into the thickest wood,
Who though he were still in this desert wood,
When he did raunge the wood for saluage game,
They fled, and fast into the wood did get:
Was wandred in the wood another way,
The Saluage forth out of the wood issew'd
And made the wood to tremble at the noyce:
That round about was bordered with a wood
But in the couert of the wood did byde,
Out of the wood he rose, and toward them did go.
To the greene wood, to gather strawberies,
A Tigre forth out of the wood did rise,
So well he wood her, and so well he wrought her,
Who when he backe returned from the wood,
And his Loue reft away, he wexed wood,
The woodborne people fall before her flat,
But with the wooddie Nymphes when she did play,
In all this forrest, and wyld wooddie raine:
The wooddy Nymphes, faire Hamadryades
And all the wooddy Nymphes did wayle and mourne.
Where now enclosd in wooden wals full faste,
And with fresh clay did close the wooden wound:
Their wooden ribs are shaken nigh a sonder;
That all the woodes and forestes did resownd;
The wyld woodgods arriued in the place,
Whence as he to those woodie hils did flie,
Emongst the woodie hilles of Dyneuowre:
After his chace on woodie Cynthus donne:
For loue amongst the woodie Gods to dwell;)
Or else some woodman shrowded there from scorching sunne.
All in a woodmans iacket he was clad
And many wilde woodmen, which robbe and rend
That with fell woodnesse he effierced was,
Amid the thickest woods. The Champion stout
And Vna wandring in woods and forrests,
Through woods and wastnesse wide him daily sought;
That all the woods with doubled Eccho ring,
Emongst wild beasts and woods, from lawes of men exilde.
Vnto the woods, to see her little sonne;
Vnto those natiue woods for to repaire,
That they the woods are past, & come now to the plaine.
The neighbour woods around with hollow murmur ring.
Through woods & mountaines, till they came at last
The woods, the Nymphes, my bowres, my midwiues weare,
As she the woods with bow and shafts did raunge,
So fortune wrought, as vnder greene woods syde
In woods, in waues, in warres she wonts to dwell,
Depart to woods vntoucht, & leaue so proud disdaine?
Through woods and plaines so long I did her chace,
Through the thicke woods, wherein he would haue hid
Or knowledge of those woods, where he did dwell,
There in await, with thicke woods ouer growne,
In those same woods, ye well remember may,
Into the woods thenceforth in hast she went,
Farre in the woods, whiles that he lay in swownd,
And mighty woods, which did the valley shade,
Seemeth that such wild woods should far expell
Yet sought the saluage woods and forrests wyde,
Shortly vnto the wastefull woods she came,
As you in woods and wanton wildernesse
Through all the woods, to search from place to place,
All couerd with thick woods, that quite it ouercame.
To walke the woods with that his Idole faire,
Now when amid the thickest woods they were,
In these wild woods, as was her wonted ioy,
Vnto those woods he turned backe againe,
Then came the Rother, decked all with woods
Vpon wyld beasts, which she in woods did find,
Through woods, and rocks, and mountaines they did draw
And his faire limbs left in the woods forlorne;
But mongst wyld beasts and saluage woods to dwell;
That all the woods and rockes nigh to that way,
That in these woods amongst the Nymphs dost wonne,
(Vnlesse thou in these woods thy selfe conceale,
Through woods and hils he follow'd him so fast,
A saluage man, which in those woods did wonne,
In seeking all the woods both farre and nye
And all the woods with piteous plaints did fill,
For nought but woods and forrests farre and nye,
Who through thicke woods and brakes & briers him drew,
As he to seeke Serena through the woods did roue.
Or wanton squirrels, in the woods farre sought,
Amongst poore hyndes, in hils, in woods, in dales,
In the woods shade, which did the waters crowne,
That through the woods their Eccho did rebound.
Was hunting in the woods (as was his trade)
Couered with shrubby woods, in which no way
He sought the woods; but no man could see there;
The woods did nought but ecchoes vaine rebound;
But all the Satyres scorne their woody kind,
And daughter of a woody Nymphe, desire
With woody mosse bedight, and all his steed
The woody Nimphs, and with that louely boy,
Till that at length vnto a woody glade
Her loue too light, to wooe a wandring guest:
Who finding litle leasure her to wooe,
Therefore he her did court, did serue, did wooe,
Could she her wished freedome fro me wooe;
And wooe with faire intreatie, to disclose,
And wooed him her Paramoure to be;
With flattering words he sweetly wooed her,
He wooed her, till day spring he espyde;
And wooed him her paramour to bee:
Before that day her wooed to his bed;
And wooed him by all the waies she could:
One day, when all that troupe of warlike wooers
Not such, as earth out of her fruitfull woomb
Being desirous (as all Knights are woont)
Right faithfull true he was in deede and word,
Though nor in word nor deede ill meriting,
Ne word to speake, ne ioynt to moue she had:
That cruell word her tender hart so thrild,
In word and deede that shew'd great modestie,
That word shall I (said he) auouchen good,
As in great muse, ne word to creature spake.
And threatned death with many a bloudie word;
A right good knight, and true of word ywis:
Let one word fall that may your griefe vnfold,
Which when I wretch,---Not one word more she sayd
Which to obserue in word of knights they did assure.
At which bold word that boaster gan to quake,
And round about the wreath this word was writ,
The merry marriner vnto his word
They forward passe, ne Guyon yet spoke word,
That word so deepe did in their harts impresse,
Nor wight, nor word mote passe out of the gate,
Through his faire daughters face, & flattring word;
Ne any noise she made, ne word she spake,
The word gone out, she backe againe would call,
Glauce, what needs this colourable word,
Ne word did speake, but lay as in a swowne,
And yet remember well the mightie word,
Ne had one word to speake, for great amaze,
The Monster swift as word, that from her went,
Ah gentle Squire (quoth he) tell at one word,
In deed Sir knight (said he) one word may tell
He courted her, yet bayted euery word,
That cheareful word his weake hart much did cheare,
As if the word so spoken, were halfe donne,
Ne word he had to speake, his griefe to tell,
But she it all refused at one word,
No word they spake, nor earthly thing they felt,
That euerie word did tremble as she spake,
Ne word he had to speake for great dismay,
His word, which on his ragged shield was writ,
Ne euer word to speake to woman more;
Yet spake no word, whereby she might aread
The noble Prince, who neuer heard one word
Ne more sincere in word and deed profest;
And she, that with her least word can asswage
And with that word him strooke, that streight he did expire.
Weigh but one word which from thy lips doth fall.
Yet the least word that euer could be layd
That neuer word from that day forth he spoke.
Much was the knight incenst with his lewd word,
Vnto your selfe, said they, we giue our word,
Till they had told their message word by word:
Till they had told their message word by word:
Of his owne mouth, that spake so warelesse word,
Sadly she rode, and neuer word did say,
With golden giftes and many a guilefull word
Much was the Knight abashed at that word;
To take defiaunce at a Ladies word
Whose euery act and word, that he did say,
Fell flat to ground, ne word vnto him sayd,
One word durst speake, or answere him a whit thereto.
That he no word could speake, but smit his brest,
For that old man of pleasing wordes had store,
Then choosing out few wordes most horrible,
But his wast wordes returnd to him in vaine:
Nor guilefull sprite, to thee these wordes doth speake,
With gentle wordes he can her fairely greet,
With fawning wordes he courted her a while,
But wordes, and lookes, and sighes she did abhore,
Nor bloudie wordes of bold Enchaunters call,
Till he these wordes to him deliuer might;
In that knights heart, and wordes with bitter teares did steepe.
Many meeke wordes, to stay and comfort her withall.
Those feeling wordes so neare the quicke did goe,
And leaning on his elbow, these few wordes let fly.
The seedes of euill wordes, and factious deedes;
And wicked wordes that God and man offended:
And still among most bitter wordes they spake,
That of no wordly thing he care did take;
Her doubtfull words made that redoubted knight
And fed with words, that could not chuse but please,
Faire Vna framed words and count'nance fit:
His louely words her seemd due recompence
Her piteous words might not abate his rage,
He neuer meant with words, but swords to plead his right.
Her words preuaild: And then the learned leach
And then to him these womanish words gan say;
With fowle reprochfull words he boldly him defide.
With fowle words tempring faire, soure gall with hony sweet.
Faire feeling words he wisely gan display,
Wherewith emmou'd, these bleeding words she gan to say.
His chearefull words reuiu'd her chearelesse spright,
Ne liuing man like words did euer heare,
And foltring tongue at last these words seemd forth to shake.
With wounding words and termes of foule repriefe
Ne let vaine words bewitch thy manly hart,
And heare the wisedome of her words diuine.
For she was able, with her words to kill,
And thereto added words of wondrous might:
With hartie words her knight she gan to cheare,
When he these bitter byting words had red,
His race with reason, and with words his will,
These words she breathed forth from riuen chest;
In these sad words she spent her vtmost breath:
And then with words & weedes of wondrous might,
Yet she with pitthy words and counsell sad,
Her gracious words their rancour did appall,
From lofty siege began these words aloud to sound.
Sweet words, like dropping honny she did shed,
To whom she thus; but ere her words ensewed,
True be thy words, and worthy of thy praise,
Of her sweet words, that all his sence dismaid,
For whiles she spake, her great words did apall
Ne chaffar words, prowd courage to prouoke,
Others sweet words, dropping like honny dew;
With percing words, and pittifull implore,
For all her words she drownd with laughter vaine,
Such powre haue pleasing words: such is the might
That weenest words or charmes may force withstond:
The rash reuengers heat. Words well dispost
Who now shall giue vnto me words and sound,
Now throwing forth lewd words immodestly;
As in approuance of his pleasing words.
For fear through want of words her excellence to marre.
His feeling words her feeble sence much pleased,
For pleasing words are like to Magick art,
These idle words (said she) doe nought asswage
Beldame, your words doe worke me litle ease;
Her chearefull words much cheard the feeble spright
Certaine sad words, with hollow voice and bace,
For he by words could call out of the sky
Th'old woman wox half blanck, those words to heare;
Her harty words so deepe into the mynd
Words fearen babes. I meane not thee entreat
So them with bitter words he stird to bloudy ire.
With sugred words and gentle blandishment,
Approching, with bold words and bitter threat,
Saying, Thou foolish knight, that weenst with words
At those proud words that other knight begonne
With flattering words he sweetly wooed her,
Which words when Paridell had heard, his hew
Of gracious speach, and skill his words to frame
And eke thy words vncourteous and vnkempt;
Her deedes were forged, and her words false coynd,
Of outrage for the words, which she heard say,
With sober words, that sufferance desired,
Such Musicke is wise words with time concented,
That to Sir Paridell these words he sent;
Whose scoffed words he taking halfe in scorne,
With golden words, and goodly countenance,
When they the reason of his words had hard,
She modest was in all her deedes and words,
For euill deedes may better then bad words be bore.
For he their words as wind esteemed light.
Which sory words her mightie hart did mate
Her words were not, as common words are ment,
Her words were not, as common words are ment,
Her spightfull words did pricke, & wound the inner part.
Though there were none her hatefull words to heare:
And with kind words accoyd, vowing great loue to mee.
No words may rate, nor rigour him remoue
With gentle words perswading them to friendly peace.
So he the words into his ballaunce threw,
But streight the winged words out of his ballaunce flew.
Wroth wext he then, and sayd, that words were light,
And so likewise of words, the which be spoken,
Much did his words the gentle Ladie quell,
For of those words, the which that boaster threw,
Now with faire words; but words did little good,
Now with faire words; but words did little good,
And with wide glauncing words, one day she thus him proued.
The art of mightie words, that men can charme;
And with faire words, fit for the time and place,
With curteous words, in the most comely wize;
Strange were the words in Britomartis eare;
Which spitefull words she sore engrieu'd to heare,
That all obedience both to words and deeds
He gan with guilefull words her to perswade,
Of euill words, and wicked sclaunders by him shed.
Euen blasphemous words, which she doth bray
O who may not with gifts and words be tempted?
Yet this in all her words might be perceiued,
Yet now some hope your words vnto me add.
But rather more enrag'd for those words sake;
He burst into these words, as to him seemed good.
And from her sory hart few heauie words forth sigh't.
That he these words burst forth; Ah sory boy,
With which his gentle words and goodly wit
Seem'd not to weigh his threatfull words at all,
Of the lewd words and deedes, which he had done:
Of senselesse words, which nature did him teach,
With such faire words she did their heate asswage,
As he the art of words knew wondrous well,
Not sparing him with bitter words to taunt;
And with reprochfull words him thus bespake on hight;
And with sharpe words did bitterly vpbrayd;
Through tempering of her words & lookes by wondrous skill.
Yet were her words and lookes but false and fayned,
Yet were her words but wynd, & all her teares but water.
Words sharpely wound, but greatest griefe of scorning growes.
What meaning mote those vncouth words comprize,
Whose sensefull words empierst his hart so neare,
Both of his words, which he with reason red;
With looks, with words, with gifts he oft her wowed;
Thus as they words amongst them multiply,
And faire bespoke with words, that he at last agreed.
Askt her, how mote her words be vnderstood,
And spake licentious words, and hatefull things
For whose sweete sake that glorious badge he wore,
She wore, with crownes and owches garnished,
And next her wrinkled skin rough sackcloth wore,
And on her head she wore a tyre of gold,
Which mortall Princes wore, whiles they on earth did rayne.
Therefore he first wore crowne of gold for dignitie.
Vpon his head he wore an Helmet light,
The golden ribband, which that virgin wore
And with their horned feet the greene grasse wore,
Which for her sake he wore, as him beseemed well.
All was through vertue of the ring he wore,
Engirt about, ne other garment wore:
And pensiue sorrow pind and wore away,
Thus many miles they two together wore,
She wore much like vnto a Danisk hood
He wore, that seemed strange to common vew,
A Chapelet of sundry flowers she wore,
She wore for her defence a mayled habergeon.
And on her legs she painted buskins wore,
Thus she all night wore out in watchfulnesse,
They wore rich Mitres shaped like the Moone,
Vppon her head she wore a Crowne of gold,
Buskins he wore of costliest cordwayne,
He wore no armour, ne for none did care,
Like to the Mores of Malaber he wore;
Looke how the Crowne, which Ariadne wore
And with new day new worke at once begin:
The other by him selfe staide other worke to doo.
Thus well instructed, to their worke they hast,
How he may worke vnto her further smarts:
To many knights did daily worke disgrace;
From euery worke he chalenged essoyne,
Leaue off their worke, vnmindfull of their smart,
A worke of wondrous grace, and able soules to saue.
At last resolu'd to worke his finall smart,
But death he could not worke himselfe thereby;
As hell she hated, chast in worke and will;
And thristy giue to drinke, a worke of grace:
And godly worke of Almes and charitee
A worke of labour long, and endlesse prayse:
To worke new woe and improuided scath,
He weened well to worke some vncouth wile,
It was an auncient worke of antique fame,
And stird you vp to worke your wilfull smarts?
One day to worke her to his will more neare,
That matter make for him to worke vpon,
Least thy foolhardize worke thy sad confusion.
To worke such shame. Therefore I thee exhort,
Or to behold the water worke, and play
A worke of rich entayle, and curious mould,
From their whot worke they did themselues withdraw
To be contrarie to the worke, which ye intend.
And part triangulare, Ã´ worke diuine;
That all this other worlds worke doth excell,
His worke, for which he was by Ioue depriued
By that same wicked witch, to worke vs dreed,
That natures worke by art can imitate:
That seemd a worke of admirable wit;
Each did the others worke more beautifie;
A worke of rare deuice, and wondrous wit.
Long worke it were, and needlesse to deuize
A simple mayd, and worke so haynous tort,
Who wonders not, that reades so wonderous worke?
And worthy worke of infinite reward,
Beldame, your words doe worke me litle ease;
During which worke the Ladie of the Lake,
Ne euer to his worke returnd againe:
Nath'lesse those feends may not their worke forbeare,
Deepe busied bout worke of wondrous end,
Not this the worke of womans hand ywis,
The beautie of his worke? Indeed in sleepe
According to their kindes. Long worke it were,
Nor Aeolus sharp blast could worke them any wrong.
To bring her backe againe, or worke her finall bale.
She there deuiz'd a wondrous worke to frame,
His worke great Troynouant, his worke is eke
His worke great Troynouant, his worke is eke
(The worke of cruell hand) was to be seene,
Seeing his worke now wasted deepe engrieued was.
Now cease your worke, and at your pleasure play:
Now cease your worke; to morrow is an holy day.
That were too long a worke to count them all;
Into this world, to worke confusion,
And euery secret worke of natures wayes,
Full busily vnto his worke ybent;
In which his worke he had sixe seruants prest,
The manner of their worke and wearie paine;
For they for nought would from their worke refraine,
To worke such outrage on so faire a creature?
Thinking to worke on her his vtmost wracke,
Thenceforth I sought by secret meanes to worke
Her worke, and counterfet her selfe so nere,
And on their foes did worke full cruell wracke:
Nor any blemish, which the worke mote blame;
It was no mortall worke, that seem'd and yet was not.
O What an endlesse worke haue I in hand,
Were worke fit for an Herauld, not for me:
Not knowing natures worke, nor what to weene,
The worke of heauens will surpasseth humaine thought.
Doth them compell to worke, to earne their meat,
That he with worke may be forwearied.
And his worke lessened, that his loue mote grow:
That he no worke at all left for the leach:
With all their force to worke auengement strong
Are wont in Princes courts to worke great scath and hindrance.
And watch aduauntage, how to worke his care:
To weet to worke Irenaes franchisement,
For thing of weight, or worke of greater care,
Should weet of me, nor worke me any wrong.
To worke his vtter shame, and throughly him confound.
Willing to worke his villenous intent
To worke by wicked treason wayes doth find,
Where he mote worke him scath and villeny.
Of sundry things, as fell, to worke delay;
Yet to occasion meanes, to worke his mind,
Thought sure t'auenge his grudge, & worke his foe great shame.
Deuized to worke delight, was gathered there,
Like as the workeman had their courses taught;
She wondred at the workemans passing skill,
The wondrous workemanship of Gods owne mould,
So goodly workemanship should not endure:
Who thereby forst his workemen to forsake,
To worken mischiefe and auenging woe,
And both against the middest meant to worken woe.
Ah who can loue the worker of her smart?
Who was the root and worker of her woe:
To his wounds worker, that with louely dart
And workes him wofull ruth.
He hated all good workes and vertuous deeds,
That workes it to his will, then he that it constraines.
Which sinfull horror workes in wounded hart,
Gainst that proud Paynim king, that workes her teene:
On them she workes her will to vses bad:
More huge in strength, then wise in workes he was,
That vnto knighthood workes much shame and woe;
Thy workes for wealth, and life for gold engage.
That she may thee aduance for workes and merites iust.
And all his workes with mercy doth embrace,
Of all Gods workes, which do this world adorne,
And that, which all faire workes doth most aggrace,
Shall find, that all the workes of those wise sages,
And workes of noblest wits to nought out weare,
Hope to endure, sith workes of heauenly wits
The goodly workes, and stones of rich assay,
The which right well her workes diuine did shew:
And all his workes with Iustice hath bedight.
To call to count, or weigh his workes anew,
Comaunded them their daily workes renew,
To doe those workes, to them appointed dew:
Is gathered full, and worketh speedy way:
Working belgards, and amorous retrate,
He had a sharpe foresight, and working wit,
That with the angry working of the waue,
All that is by the working of thy Deitee.
Through working of the stone therein yset.
She through her wicked working did incense,
That neither day nor night from working spared,
Many vaine fancies, working her vnrest;
Working to all, that loue her, deadly woe,
And spake the praises of the workmans wit;
Which goodly order, and great workmans skill
With murmure soft, that seem'd to serue the workmans will.
Or could be fram'd by workmans rare deuice;
Did th'other far in workmanship excell;
This parts great workmanship, & wondrous powre,
Ne ought their goodly workmanship might saue
So hard a workmanship aduenture darre,
With which high God his workmanship hath deckt;
